item.description:
Superstar is a sports-themed family game that actually consists of five different sub-games, viz. Cross Country, Swimming, Shooting, Shot Put and Basketball. Each of the sub-games is represented by it's own roll-and-move, or dice rolling, track on the game board. Players get rewarded by game money ("Superdollars") for relative success in each sub-game - but those who land on the feared "Doping Test" space will be immediately disqualified from that particular sport! The player with most Superdollars at the end will be declared "Superstar" and given a quadruple hurrah by her fellow players.

The catch of the game is that the 18 chance cards actually instruct players to do physical exercises, such as push-ups, stretching etc., and a player unable or unwilling to do those will have to pass a turn.

item.description:
At the start of the 19th century, the exploration and exploitation of the African continent began in earnest. During this deplorable period in world history, the major European powers — Britain, Holland and France — would mercilessly explore, colonize and fight over its many resources for a hundred years. Naturally, native populations would come to resent and rebel against their foreign exploiters and seek independence, and so it is in this swift-playing game for two, where you emulate a European nation and compete for a continent.

Players get a hand of cards in four types: Explore, Colonize, Exploit and Conflict. Some cards are restricted to a region, others to a single area. Exploration leads to colonization, which leads to exploitation, and sometimes to a conflict between the rival powers. Hand management and timely card play is important in this game.

If more colonists arrive in an area than it will accept, a native uprising will occur. The roll of a die and simple charts settle uprisings (and conflicts) quickly. Choosing the right time to initiate negative action against your opponent can be crucial.

INFILTRATE ANTICIPATE CAPTURE

Illyricum 6 - 9 CE

During the period of Rome’s bloody civil wars, a divided army fought for control of one of the mightiest empires on earth. Take sides in a game that balances skill and chance. Anticipate and plot your next moves, as you scheme to infiltrate and plunder enemy territory. Ambush and capture your opponents, but beware! Fickle Roman gods may take sides and intercede to seal your fate.

Your moves are determined by the cards you draw. Uncertainty haunts your every turn, because sprinkled among the tiles are Roman gods that may aid or impede your efforts.

The perfect balance between strategy and chance in the unpredictable Ancient World. Young players will particularly love the unpredictability and surprise while older players will treasure and master the infinite playing strategies.

Played on an 8 x 8 board with marble pieces and a stack of cards full of mystical and powerful gods.

To understand what you get, we uploaded a great range of photos on this BGG page. The Production Version is the standalone box set. Capere is a Social Abstract Game SAG for 2 or 4 players.

CAPERE IS ALSO AVAILABLE WITH WOODEN TILES AS PART OF ANCIENT WORLD MULTI GAME SYSTEM FROM PLAYFORD GAMES

From the publisher:

Take gaming to a whole new scale with Fishy Tactics - you'll be hooked! 
An easy to learn, quick to play, 2-4 player board game of fish, fun and tactics for ages 4+.

"This lake ain't big enough for the 2-4 of us!" Quarrelling fishermen try to outmanoeuvre each other to catch the best fish for their tea. Some fish are more valuable than others, but will your line reach? Or will someone swipe your prized whopper from your haul? Oh and watch out for the crocodile!

Players take it in turns to 1) spin the spinner and move the crocodile one space along the grid and remove any fish it lands on from the game and then 2) roll the fisher's die (regular d6) and move any one fish on the grid x number of squares toward them. If the fish reaches your basket it's yours!
Rolled a 6? Instead of moving a fish, select a player and steal blind one fish from their haul.

Play finishes when the last fish leaves the lake - and the player with the most points of fish in their boat at the end of the game wins!

item.description:
It is the 25th century. You are a member of an intergalactic expedition shipwrecked on a mysterious planet named Artemia. While waiting for the rescue ship, you begin to explore the planet but an alien entity picks up your scent and begins to hunt you. You are NOT ALONE! Will you survive the dangers of Artemia?

NOT ALONE is an asymmetrical card game, in which one player (the Creature) plays against the stranded explorers (the Hunted).

If you play as one of the Hunted, you will explore Artemia using Place cards. By playing these and Survival cards, you try to avoid, confuse or distract the Creature until help arrives.

If you play as the Creature, you will stalk and pursue the shipwrecked survivors. By playing your Hunt cards and using the mysterious powers of Artemia, you try to wear down the Hunted and assimilate them to the planet forever.

NOT ALONE is a immersive, thematic card game, where you use guessing, bluffing, hand management, and just a pinch of deck-building to achieve your goal, which is survival for the Hunted... or total assimilation for the Creature!

item.description:
What would your house look like? Would you rather have a huge bedroom with an elegant canopy bed or a spacious living room with a grand piano? You are going to play a part of designers who will plan a house and add more and more rooms to it.

Dream Home is a family game about building and furnishing your new house. Over twelve rounds, players collect pairs of cards consisting of a room card and an accessory card (roof, helper, furnishing or tool) and place them on their personal boards, creating their dream homes.

At the end of the game, all players’ houses are finished and fully furnished. Players compare their houses, counting points for functionality, good design, quality of roof and furnishing. The player with the nicest and most comfortable house wins.

item.description:
Overview (by the publisher): At the tournament place, the knights want to prove themselves. The colored symbol dice are thrown into the dice tower, showing new challenges every turn. The various symbols and colors have to be sorted. Which is the largest set? Skill is necessary when flicking the pieces. The more dice match the target space, the further the Knight can move.

Gameplay: The active player throws the six dice and a small wooden cube into the dice tower. The player then flicks a wooden disk. If he hits one of the target spaces, he claims the dice that show the matching result (color or symbol). Then the other players in turn order also flick the disk to try to claim some of the remaining dice. After this, the next player becomes the active player, and continues with throwing all dice into the tower.

Each die collected moves the player's knight one step forward. The first knight reaching to other side of the tower wins.

There are also rules for a variant in which the players bet which symbol they will roll, get points for matching symbols, and are able to change their bet by paying dice.

Put yourself in place of the greatest heroes and commanders of Argentina's history and free this land with honor, wisdom and strategy. Oid Mortales el grito sagrado. LIBERTAD!

Oíd Mortales is a trivia game with strategy combat in a board. Players will have to manage tokens, playing infantry and artillery cards which will fight in surprise trivia, where be the expert historian is not necessarily good. The tactic board gives an expansion to the game far beyond questions and answers, where movement and intelligent use of resources is important as the battle itself.

Each player will take the side of the "Patriotas" and the other the "Realista´s" side. During the game the players draw cards and put or move the battalions on the map in relation to the action points (AP) obtained in the die roll.

Each team will have 4 commanders that have special fight habilities, one of them will be the Gold Commander.

The dice roll give action points (AP) to the players. The actions cost from 2 AP to 6 AP, depending on the type of action. For example take an artillery card cost 2 AP but an event card cost 6 AP.

When a unit is next to an enemy unit, the player can attack. Each artillery or reinforcement card, wich are used to attack, include an historical trivia. The attacker increase or decrease his AP by answering de question.

The first player who eliminate the enemy Gold Commander enemy wins.

item.description:
Battle Roads Miniatures is a table top board game set in a post apocalyptic world where civilization is rebuilding itself. A plague whose origin is not widely known wiped out most of the population. Attempts to isolate and purge the cause resulted in wide spread use of major nuclear arsenals and other weapons of mass destruction. Not much was left. Very few people were left. Those that survived found that they had undergone changes.

The technology in the cars is 20 to 40 years past the "weld on a gun, add some steel plate and go get stuck in" that immediately followed the plague and attempted purges. Vehicles are purpose built for their combat role and are far more deadly. Driver protection is at a premium so motorcycles have mostly been relegated to the few remaining fringe gangs. The mortality rate for motorcycle users is so high they are now called "coffins".

The goal is to survive the game and take out as many opponents' cars as possible. Game play is very fast with each turn lasting 3 to 10 minutes depending on how many cars are on the board. Each player uses a control board for each car that tracks turn speed, two phases of movement, component damage, and driver skill use (offense or defense). For the convention play version of the game these control boards are made of wood. For the mass production version (digital image in gallery), the control boards will be on silk screen impregnated boards (~5mm thick). Players track their car status and maneuvers by placing colored pegs on the control board.

Combat is via opposed dice roles. The attacker gets a pool of dice based on the weapon being shot and the range, speed and direction the target is moving. Driver skill can also add to the attack dice pool. The defender gets defense dice equal to their remaining armor rating and can get additional dice for range, speed and driver skill. Once rolled, any offensive successes over defense score damage. Critical damage is a big part of the game. Any time an attack rolls any successes their is a crit chance. It is extremely unlikely an undamaged car will take a critical hit but a medium to heavily damage car is highly likely to take a critical. The bad news with critical damage is the attacker assigns the damage location. Basically, the attacker hits what his/her driver was aiming for. Critical hits are to be feared and avoided!

Rules can be played at the Quick Play level, standard level or with all optional rules. The largest change between levels is how to handle collisions. Many diagrams are included in the rules to simplify the learning process and reduce the "rules lawyering" that may occur when questions arise.

Each game is played via individual scenario or players can play the long term campaign where they control an entire tribe including all their cars as well as drivers and advanced facilities. As drivers score damage, score critical damage, make kills and win scenarios they gain points that allow them to increase in driver skill or obtain upgrades for their cars. The core version of battle roads miniatures includes basic upgrades for the base cars like a bigger engine, bigger weapons, etc. A later expansion will include full design and upgrades of the cars.

Autocross is a vintage dice rolling board game, up to 6 can play. Players try to avoid the green, yellow and red spaces. Three lights shows on the right of the board, when a car steps onto one of these spaces.

Green light: one space back and miss one turn
Yellow light: two spaces back and miss two turns
Red light: go back to start

The first to get the finish, wins.

Contents:
6 cars
1 dice
1 board

You need a 4.5 V battery to use the lights (not included).

item.description: Each player has 6 meeples, which he must get from his starting spaces to the 6 numbered home spaces of his color. Each meeple has to move once around the board. Movement is determined by a die. Meeples are brought into play by rolling a 1. The blue spaces on the track are neutral and can hold more than one meeple. On the yellow spaces, meeples can be thrown out. But this is actually a good thing, because they are put on the home spaces of their color. Throwing out is mandatory. If a Player forgets to throw another meeple out, one of the meeples in his home is put back to a starting space. If a meeple is thrown out on the space of his own color in front of his home, the meeple is put back on a starting space. The first player to bring his 6 meeples home wins the game.

The players start with 6 meeples at the bottom of the game board. Movement is determined by a die. Any meeple that has reached space 25 can advance to a winning space by the apt roll of the die. For instance, on the roll of a 2 it can occupy a "100-space" or on the roll of a 6 the "1000-space". Each winning space con only be occupied by one meeple. The game ends when all winning spaces are occupied or all meeples are on winning spaces. The player with the highest point count wins the game.

In Alpha Bet players take turns writing words in a shared grid. Each player has three copies of the alphabet to draw letters from, plus an additional copy of the alphabet and pool of vowels available to all players.

When a player creates a word they first write it down in a separate area and bet points per letter. Their opponents then write down letters they think will appear in this word and also make per-letter bets. The player will gain the points bet for letters no opponent guesses and lose them for guessed letters; their opponents gain points for correct guesses and lose them for incorrect guesses.

In Cross-Wordsmith players enter words into a grid. Unlike in most such games each grid space does not contain a letter but a section of a word: a prefix, root, or suffix. Many of the grid spaces are color-coded to show which of the three they must contain, while others can have any section.

A list of allowable sections is provided; on their turn a player chooses at least one of these to add to the grid and marks off all they use (each one can only be used a certain number of times). All adjacent word sections must combine into words, but this does not necessarily have to be done linearly; it is possible to turn corners when forming words.

Each word section has a point value and players score for all words they form on each turn.

TECH? NO! 
Forget about expensive game systems, emulators, disconnected online games, and high-priced yearly roster updates. TECHNO BOWL takes everything you love about arcade and video game football classics like Tecmo Bowl, NFL Blitz, and Madden and puts it all on the tabletop.

1UP
And as if that isn’t cool enough, it also gives you a feature that gamers have long asked for but never gotten… until now! What is it you ask? As a coach in TECHNO BOWL, you will design your own formations and plays. That’s right. Let me say it again. You get to design your own formations and plays.

And I’m not talking about choosing several formation cards, lining up elements on a chart, or utilizing some other abstraction. This is putting the power to effortlessly create real football formations and plays into your hands.

ZERO DOWN TIME
Thanks to the BOX SPORTS ENGINE, there is almost zero down time in the game [except for half time and timeouts of course!]. Coaches are constantly involved, and the on-field players are always interacting with one another as skill checks and ever evolving plays result in: free actions, reactions, read-and-reacts, and offensive and defensive adjustments. Add to that real world timers for setting up formations and selecting plays, and you have a truly dynamic fast-paced tabletop football experience.

UNPARALLELED FOOTBALL GAMEPLAY
TECHNO BOWL delivers that authentic football feel like no game before it. Establish the running game by punching it in between the tackles or tossing it to a back for an outside sweep. Launch an air offensive while sitting in the pocket or throwing on the run with laser accurate throws directly to the receiver or exciting route passes where you lead the receiver in hopes of beating the coverage. Defense can run man, zone, and mixed defensive packages and bring the blitz. Oh, can it bring the blitz!

No matter which strategy you choose, the gameplay will look, feel, and flow like a real football play.

OPTIONS
TECHNO BOWL is all about options, and there’s a game mode, team, and play style for everyone. You even have the option to run an option!

MODES
There are five different modes of play. Each of these brings a different experience to the table.

- TECHNO is 7-vs-7 with no skills and no field goals.
- ALL TECHNO is 7-vs-7 with skills but no field goals.
- INFERNO! It’s ALL TECHNO with more awesome and fire! [more later]
- PRO is 8-vs-8 with no skills but includes field goal rules.
- ALL PRO is 8-vs-8 with skills and field goal rules.

Each of these modes offers a completely different game experience, and I know what you’re thinking. How does adding an extra couple of players to the field [and the ability to kick field goals] equate with an entirely different mode? Trust me. Having that extra player on both sides of the ball quite literally changes everything.

MAD SKILLS
When playing in modes that utilize special skills and abilities, coaches will have access to three types of players:

- IMPACT
- STAR
- SUPERSTAR

These players will come equipped with one or more of the 26 skills found in the game. That count of 26 skills doesn’t even include core fundamentals or INFERNO MODE specific skills.

SKILL
Speaking of skills, TECHNO BOWL is a game of skill and not a random ‘dice fest’. The 2d6 rolls used for skill checks mean that coaches won’t fall prey to straight-line probabilities or random chaos. Winning is about getting the right match and modifiers to deliver a high percentage roll, having a plan when you get an unusually poor result, and knowing the right time to make a high risk roll for a shot at a very high payoff. Of course, your formations, play calling, and player positioning create these opportunities.

PLAYMAKER DIE
The PLAYMAKER die powers some of the special skills in the game like stiff arms and spin moves allowing for sophisticated passive abilities to be triggered without the need for complex rules.

TEAMS
There are 32 teams in the MORE FUN LEAGUE [MFL], and each of these has its own unique play style. This means that you’re not just trying to get into the head of the coach that’s sitting across the table from you, but that you have to take into consideration the strengths and weaknesses of the players on the specific rosters that you and your opponent are using.

PLAYER SKILL RATINGS
The player skill rating system ensures that coaches and spectators will know how well or poorly a player performs fundamental actions by simply looking at the jersey number! No need to look at charts or extended stat lines. The league skill cap manages team composition so that you are never taxed to remember an insane number of special abilities or which players have them. Coaches get beaten by other coaches and NOT the rules.

Welcome to the More Fun League!

item.description:
A set of three games for two players (hence the title). All are public domain games:

Dots & Dashes is Boxes.
Sting is Jotto.
Maneuvres is Battleship.

Side-Swap is an abstract strategy game with similarities to Checkers. The pieces start on squares of the opposite color and have to cross the board to their home area on the other side, at which time they can move onto squares of their own color; after they do this they cannot move again. All pieces can be jumped and jumps can be chained. Opposing pieces can only be captured once they have moved onto their color spaces.

The game can be played by two players, four players in partnerships, or four players individually. When playing with four the pieces are turned over to show numbers; pieces must end up on the spaces with matching numbers. The four-individuals game has a few extra rules about when pieces of the same color may be captured.

Do you like gnomes? Do you like cookies?? Then prepare yourself for the most EPIC CARD GAME EVER! Steal the Cookie is a fast paced, intense party card game. The object of the game is to be the last player with the Almighty Cookie in your hand, when the final Cookie Jar Card is drawn.

The game consists of three types of cards... Action cards, Stop Cards, and Interrupt Cards. Each player must use the cards in his hand to prevent the other players from obtaining the cookie. The game is easy to learn, but hard to master. Use all of your skills to overcome your opponents and steal the COOKIE! But watch out! Your opponents have an array of spells and tricks up their sleeve! The object of the game is to be the last player to be holding the Almighty Cookie when the final Cookie Jar card is drawn. The game is fast, simple, and incredibly easy to learn. There are over 20 different card types for endless hours of fun! So grab your friends and family and get ready to STEAL THE COOKIE!

Czech board game about rally racing. 
Players roll the dice and drive through track that consists of 3 stages. Every stage has speed trials, precise stops, failure traps and other tasks that can cause penalties to player. When all players finish stage, next one can start. Players count their penalties in the finish of race. Winner is player with the least penalties.
Trivia game about the german Tv-Series "Tatort"

Mixed Nuts is a party/trivia game with a unique voting element. Each of the trivia cards is double-sided with a question on both sides and the answer to each question on the opposite side; therefore, the person reading the question can play along, too. Each card features an odd trivia fact—and somewhere in the text, there are two possible choices—one is a fact, the other is a fib (these choices are a different color than the rest of the text).

The active player picks one (the fact or the lie), and reads the sentence aloud to the other players. Here's an example: “Al Capone's vault was opened on live TV by (Barbara Walters/Geraldo Rivera) and there was virtually nothing of value in it.” Players then decide if the given answer was correct. For instance, the active player includes “Barbara Walters” in their statement. If a player thinks that's right, they put the voting chip in their hand. If a player thinks that’s incorrect, they put nothing in their hand and have an empty hand. All players then reveal what's in their hand. The correct answer is “Geraldo Rivera,” so those players with empty hands receive one point—in the form of a nut—to put into their score cup. After three rounds of each player having had a turn to read a card, the player with the most nuts wins.

item.description:
With the shopping cart in the supermarket. Where is the shelf with the bananas or the milk? Colored chits have to be sorted into the correct shelves and counters, before they can be added to the cart and paid at the checkout.

The main game is a memory variant, in which the players don't have to find pairs; instead, they need to find food items that match the colored spaces in their shopping basket.

In addition, there are several simple rules for play whith very young childs: just naming the various objects, sorting the items into she correct shelves, moving them around with the plastic shopping cart, buying their favourite dish ...

item.description:
The Pyramid of the Flying Marbles is a Shibumi game for 3 players derived from The House of the Flying Blades, by the same designer.

Players take turns capturing a marble of the next player in turn or passing. When all players pass in succession the game ends. The player with more marbles remaining on the board wins.

item.description:
Mauseschlau and Bärenstark want to recover a treasure from a ship wreck deep in the ocean. But the diving is not without risks. There are aggressive sharks, and a mysterious creature guards the wreck. By he who can answer questions and perform tasks related to ships and oceans, and has a little luck with the dice, will be first to bring his treasure to safety.

It is a roll-and-move game where the players follow a track through the sea, from the ship to the diving bell, from there to the ship wreck, and upwards to the surface.

On many spaces, a question related to the sea will be asked; younger childs can select between three answers on the card, older ones have to find the answer without help. On other spaces, a small pantomime is requested. In both cases, oxygen tanks can be won. These are needed on the shark spaces. Without air, the player has to retreat to the diving bell.

When reaching or passing the wreck, the player gets a piece of the treasure.

On addition to sharks, the area between the ship wreck and the surface is guarded by a plastic Kraken. It is moved by a special die, and if it catches a diver with treasure, the treasure is lost, and the player is send back to the diving bell. When a player reaches the surface with a treasure, he wins the game.

Changes to the precursor (Mauseschlau & Bärenstark: Abenteuer unter Wasser) include: Less shark spaces, especially in the last part after the ship wreck; an additional die for the kraken, so the players can move the kraken in addition to their own playing piece; the treasure is easier to get, since the wreck no longer needs to be reached with the exact die roll; a variant is included to make it easier to leave the sea with the treasure. As a result, this revised game plays in half the time, and has less luck of the dice.

Google translation:

Goal of the game:
Purchase as many properties. But winning is not who has acquired the most extensive possessions but who could invest the most.

Aus der Spielregel (German)

Ziel des Spiels:
Erwerben Sie möglichst viele Liegenschaften. Sieger ist aber nicht, wer den umfangreichsten Besitz erworben hat, sondern wer am meisten investieren konnte.

Challenge your brain! See how you stack up in 4 mind-bending categories.

National Geographic Channel's Brain Games unlocks the science behind the mysteries of why we say, see, feel, and act the way we do! Whether you're going HEAD-TO-HEAD against another player or playing solo, you will discover loopholes in YOUR perception of REALITY.

In Brain Games, players take turns rolling a die to move 1-3 spaces and then try to pass the mind-bending challenge from the category (Logic, Language, Vision, or Mind & Body) they landed on to earn a token. The first player to get a token in each category wins the game! But be careful, the Head-To-Head challenges make you choose an opponent to take the challenge with but only the winner gets the token.

item.description:
Backstory

The great Space Disagreement of 5406 has forced your entire colony to flee into the dark depths of outer space. You’re not alone. Other colonies too seek refuge from the war. All scramble to harvest the valuable resources on undiscovered planets. Your mission: destroy all other colonies. Diplomacy is boring. Shoot first, confirm if they were enemies later...

Description

Mothership combines miniatures, strategy and dice combat games into an easy to pick up experience that everyone can enjoy. Control a fleet of ships and charge through the galaxy, capturing planets, building defences and amassing powerful technologies. 
Play Deathmatch Mode in a gripping, last-man standing fight for power or play the fast and frantic Victory Point Mode. With game play that’s built from the ground up to eliminate end-game drag, you’ll find Mothership to be light-hearted, engaging and thrilling from start to finish.

Features: 
Modular Board - Endless combinations means you’ll never play the same game twice
Control Panel - Puts you in charge of managing power on your Mothership
Light Mechanics - A Sci-Fi board game that cuts right to the combat. Light on weight, heavy on fun!

item.description:
Among Thieves is a fast-paced card game of thievery, cunning and dishonorable deeds.

Each player takes the role of a thief, trying to prove his superiority over the others by amassing a greater fortune. Everyone starts with the same set of action cards and each turn selects two, placing them face-down in front of him. Then, starting with the Acting Master Thief (first player), all players take turns in revealing one of their cards and completing its effect. This is repeated for the second card. At the end of the round, if there is no winner, all players discard one action card and play continues in the same fashion.

Every action differs from the others - some allow you to gain gold by robbing innocent citizens, some let you sabotage the plans of other players, and - of course - one of the actions enables you to steal directly from the fortunes of other players.

Among Thieves is a game of constant interaction between players, offers a unique mixture of strategy and intuition, and gives you the chance to prove once and for all to your friends who the real Master Thief is.

item.description:
Czech game with large board full of castles and paths. 
Players recruit one knight every turn, position of new knight is controlled by dice. After that players can move to consolidate power of knights to groups or fight for castles or other groups/knights or avoid conflicts etc. If someone wins battle for castle chooses carefully hidden defense power of castle (becouse it is limited per player). 
Game ends when there is only last free castle. Players sum their castle points and player with the most wins.

Star is a two-player abstract strategy game designed by Ea Ea as the third out of four games by him extending or generalizing Hex. The four games in publication order: The Game of Y, Poly-Y, Star, and *Star. See further details of the developmental history at the designer's homepage.

The game board for Star is a hexagon with uneven side lengths made up of hexagonal spaces (e.g. alternating edge length of 6 and 7 hexes). On the board, the playing area is surrounded by a ring of "partial edge hexagons" used for final scoring. The two players (black and white) takes turns to place one stone (in their color) on any un-occupied hex space in the playing area. The goal of the game is to create "stars" - groups of connected stones belonging to one player that touches at least three partial edge hexagons. Each star has a score of the number of partial edge hexagons it touches minus two. The final score of a player is the sum of points for all the stars of that players color. The player with the highest score wins. The sum of the two players score is constant for any particular board.

From Wikipedia:
Star is a two-player abstract strategy board game developed by Craige Schensted (now Ea Ea). It was first published in 1983 in Games magazine. It is a connection game, related to games such as Hex, Y, Havannah, and TwixT. Unlike these games, however, the result is based on a player having a higher final score rather than achieving a specific goal. He has since developed a slightly more complicated version called *Star with better balance between edge and center moves, writing "*Star is what those other games wanted to be."

Aren't we all a bit DAWAK? Are you ready for more than 1000 crezy questions and tasks? Then this crazy party fun is just for you. Who wants to become Dawak champion needs to be fast and clever: Only the one who gives the correct answer first scores.

Contents: A "punch" card that goes to the center of the table. 9 plastic pieces (3 forms/colors, 3 sizes) around them. And a stack of 107 quiz cards (double side, 4 questions and one Dawak section on each side).

Players take turns as the host, who first rolls the die. On a roll of 1-4, he reads the corresponding question. A player who thinks he knows the answer has to hit the "punch" card in the middle of the table, and then he has three seconds to answer. The first player who gives the correct answer gets the card (max one answer per player)

The last 2 sides of the die show the word "Dawak". The dawak section on the card tells what to do now. Often, the players have to grab a specific one or several of the plastic pieces in the center. In other cases, the host has to mime something, sum a melody, sing a song, or the like. The players have to regonize it to claim the card.

Game ends when one player has collected 7 cards. He wins.

item.description:
From the cover:

Mission: Capture Berlin before the Americans/British!
Method: Massive ground assault from Oder Bridgehead
Ground Conditions: Mud
Enemy Strength: Fanatical Nazis, SS troops and Volksturm. Resistance cannot last beyond a few days. Morale seems to be good despite other reports.
Fuel situation critical. Ammunition limited. We will bury the Nazis.

Ni-Ju ("20" in japanese) is a tile laying game for 2 players.

In Ni-Ju, players compete to create the pattern depicted on at least one of their tiles by surrounding that same tile with other tiles. Each player has 20 tiles and each tile has a different pattern, hence the name of the game (20). There are 70 different patterns if we include rotations.

item.description:
From the designer:

Create your city and be the best mayor in the history over the 4 years (4 rounds in each year)! Set goals, fulfill promises, create your strategy and grow your city while maintaining the best levels of education, health, sustainability (ecology), security, entertainment and economy.

Each player purchases (with cash) Construction Tiles (houses, apartments, hospitals, cinemas, schools, industries etc) which will enhance the different levels of your city (security, health, education etc).

With high levels the player can complete Goal Cards that he acquired during rounds and also complete the requests of the television media (media cards), earning more points mayor and approval of the population. Implement projects (through project cards) can also help gain mayor points, gain approval of the population and increase the city levels.

To buy Construction Tiles, Goal Cards and Projects Cards, each player uses his meeples (city hall employees). Throughout the game, new meeples may be hired.

At the end of each year, players must have high approval of the population to gain even more Mayor Points. At the end of 4 years, which has more points Mayor is the winner!

From the designer (Portuguese):

Construa a sua cidade e seja o melhor prefeito da história ao longo de 4 anos (4 rodadas em cada ano)! Estabeleça metas, cumpra promessas, crie sua estratégia e faça crescer a sua cidade, mantendo os melhores níveis de educação, saúde, sustentabilidade (ecologia), segurança, lazer e economia.

Cada jogador compra com dinheiro Tiles de Construção (casas, apartamentos, hospitais, cinemas, escolas, indústrias etc.) que irão aumentar os diferentes níveis de sua cidade (segurança, saúde, educação etc.).

Com os níveis elevados, o jogador poderá completar Cartas de Objetivo que ele adquiriu durante as rodadas e também concluir as solicitações da mídia de televisão (cartões de mídia), ganhando mais pontos de prefeito e aprovação da população. Implementar projetos (através de cartões de projetos) também pode ajudar a ganhar pontos de prefeito, obter a aprovação da população e aumentar os níveis da cidade.

Para comprar tiles de construção, cartões de objetivos e cartões de projetos, cada jogador usa seus meeples (funcionários da prefeitura). Durante o jogo, novos meeples podem ser contratados.

No final de cada ano, os jogadores devem ter alta de aprovação da população para ganhar ainda mais pontos de prefeito. No final de 4 anos, que tiver mais pontos de prefeito é o vencedor!

Humanity has inherited the stars, but humanity being what it is, the stars forever slip from its grasp. Even the First Sovereignty, which scattered humanity to a million worlds, has collapsed, consigned to oblivion. No one remembers what brought it about, whether a withering apathy, rebellions across its repressed worlds, or the impenetrable whims of the enigmatic, inhuman Xeno. Yet humanity is tenacious. There are always more fledgling civilizations ready to rise to the heights of power and culture, invent new technologies, and usher in a new millennium.

Deep Future is a card-driven board game for 1-3 players of empire and innovation spanning the rise and fall of the countless worlds of the galaxy. You will settle on planets, expand your influence across sectors, invent new technologies and rediscover old ones, and face challenges that threaten to tear your civilization apart as you try to achieve one of several paths to victory.

Deep Future is a “Make-as-You-Play” game, which means that the game starts with a few materials (a map, paper, index cards, and colored cubes) and the remaining components will be generated as needed during play. Each game will see the addition of new cards, which represent the worlds in the galaxy, the techs invented, and the lasting impact of previous civilizations.

The rules include tables and guidelines for creating new cards as needed, and this makes every copy of Deep Future an evolving galaxy. In addition, it means that each game inherits all components added or changed in the previous games. The galaxy’s content — its worlds, techs, and history — can grow endlessly over a connected campaign as players return to see what each new era holds for the future of humanity.

Goblins en la mina is a filler card game for 2 to 6 players, with playing time of 30-45 minutes. The objective of the game is to be the first in amassing a determinate number of gold ingots (depending of the number of players). To achieve this aim, the players can explore the mine, fighting monsters and facing other dangers. Is also possible to get the gold attacking other player’s dungeons, if you find one of the old hidden passageways to do it...

Each player takes the role of a goblin dungeon master in order to create his own dungeon, choosing between the different types of goblins, and building different rooms to upgrade the dungeon. 
Goblins en la mina is crazy humorously game for all the family, and the art is done to create this atmosphere. Lots of fun and laughts are assured with each play of this game. 
Goblins is also a game that contributes (giving part of its benefits) to a solidarity association called Ayudar Jugando. This association works and collaborates in different causes related with children in difficult situations.

item.description:
The Imperium Chronicles Combat Card Game is an easy-to-understand, fast-paced game between two players. Players alternate between being the Attacker and the Defender, each using a Unit Card and multiple Modifier Cards each round. The winner of each round earns a point and the first player to reach 10 points wins the game.

Note: You only need to buy ONE deck for BOTH players to play! A single deck includes everything you need for two players!

Parallel is a 2-4 four player light-weight matching card game of deduction and strategy. Play consists of being dealt (4) randomized playing cards; followed by the clockwise execution of various actions in a race to match the goal card in the center. This means that each players goal is unique to their perspective of the goal card. After the cards are dealt, each players stands them keeping them secret. Each round consists of checking for matches, and execution of actions until one player claims victory. Players begin with (4) action tokens and lose one for every match. Action tokens replenish at the beginning of each players turn, after their first turn. 
 Their are two types of actions. The Swap and Switch actions effect your cards, while the Flip and Spin action effect the goal card. This is important because players cannot win on the same turn as manipulating their own cards. This means, in order to win, a player must come into their turn having 4 matching, a winning board state, or have the ability to Flip or Spin the goal card into a winning position. Winning a round grants a VP token.

For more on Parallel please follow @ParallelCG on twitter or check out Parallel.Mozello.Com

link.value: 9 Card Game Print and Play Design Contest

item.description:
Mishmash Galaxy is a light strategy game of long-term planning, memorization and card management in which you combine made-believe substances to complete and construct the staples of SF technologies! Make clichés and tropes come to life as you struggle to create FTL drives, time machines, portals and laser weaponry!

The goal of the game is to be the player with the most victory points! Players can earn victory points mostly by completing technologies; whenever a technology is completed, all contributors get the minor score of that technology, and if there is a major contributor, that player earns the major score. On a turn, a player can execute two actions, none of which are obligatory. The actions are:

• Play a Research Card: A player can put one of their Substance Card face down in front of them. At the beginning of their next turn, this card is revealed and its research ability is activated. Then the card should be discarded. You can never have more than one active Research Card.

• Contribute to a Technology: Each player can contribute a card from their hand to two different Technologies. Any card can be contributed (Ingredient or Substance) as long as the resource of the card are correct with the resources needed in that Technology stage. Each Technology is being filled in order of their blueprint, from left to right. You play the cards face down and place your ownership token on the card. Resolving the Technology works as below:


 All cards on the Technology are revealed.
 Cards are then activated from right to left. Owner of the card is the one who resolves the card Technology ability.


The game ends when all Technologies prepared for the game are completed.

item.description: In Djumble, players reveal cards from the deck that have descriptions such as "green", "floats", or "weighs more than 1 kg", then everyone races around the house — or wherever they're playing — to find something that fits as many of these categories as possible, then they argue about which things fit best in order to score points.

item.description:
Believing you've made the archaeological discovery of a lifetime, you and your intrepid partner enter the lost pyramid of Naal'ru, only to be immediately trapped in an endless Lovecraftian Dreamscape full of maddening visions of terror.

Mad Love is a co-operative pocket card game of memory and deduction for 2 people played with a deck of just 18 cards.

From the designer:

Control Tower: LAX Airport is a family boardgame about the management of the planes in an airport.
The players are air controllers who must land and take off the planes and distribute those planes in the diferent areas of the airport like repair/maintenance garage or refuelling to satisfice their requeriments.

The game is based on Control Tower with new mechanism.
The players share the LAX Airport while in Control Tower each player manage his own airport. This change makes different feelings between both games.

Control Tower: LAX Airport is an addictive boargame for 2 to 5 players, with easy rules but complex making decisions.

From the designer (Spanish):

"Torre de Control" es un juego de mesa familiar sobre la gestión de aviones en un aeropuerto.
Los jugadores encarnan a controladores aéreos de la gestión interna de un aeropuerto y entre sus funciones están ordenar los aterrizajes y despegues de los aviones y las distribución de los aviones en los diferentes servicios del aeropuerto tales como repostaje y reparación y mantenimiento.

El juego esta basado en "Torre de Control" pero con nuevas mecánicas. En esta versión los jugadores tienen un único aeropuerto común a diferencia de la anterior versión que cada jugador tenia el suyo propio. Este cambio hace que ambas versiones transmitan unas sensaciones de juego totalmente diferentes.

"Torre de control: Aeropuerto LAX" es un juego adictivo de 2 a 5 jugadores, de reglas muy sencillas pero con mucha toma de decisiones.

name.value: Dirty Cops: A Game for Scoundrels

item.description:
Dirty Cops: A Game for Scoundrels is a fast paced 2-4 player game where players work cooperatively against criminals, then stab each other in the back to gain the most money.

Games take place over 3-4 crime scenes, depending on player count, with each player taking on the role of lead detective during the course of the game.

Players choose how much they work together, making (and breaking) alliances with each other to survive the criminals (and other cops). Players also choose how ruthless they want to be with each other, allowing the group to set the tone for the game.

Cops, drugs, and guns...what kind of cop will YOU be?

Real-time game, in which up to 6 players must simultaneously and continuously play cards to its own boards trying to defeat at least one of the different powers of any of the opponent's cards and take them. The effects of the played cards are instantaneous and change the powers and abilities of other cards in play.

It's a fast and frenetic game, that can be played even with kids.
The game is played in rounds until the deck is empty (more players means less time). When this happens, the players count the total strength of the defeated cards, and who has more is declared winner.
It can also be played in constructed deck mode.

name.value: A Curious Deck for Extraordinary Liars

item.description:
This is the first of a series of games based on some simple rules... Here's the description from the back of the box:

A Curious Deck for Extraordinary Liars contains 56 peculiar cards depicting surreal and unintentionally hilarious Victorian art from ads and postcards dated 1880-1910.

Instructions for play:
The first player takes a card from the deck. The card holder may choose to describe what they see on the card or lie about what is on the card. It's up to the other players to determine whether the card holder is lying or telling the truth. Players are permitted to ask questions.

When all players have guessed Lie or Truth, the card holder announces the correct answer and reveals the card.

The player to the left then takes a new card from the deck and continues the game.

Players who guess correctly get 1 point.

The first player to 10 points wins.

Mother Truckers is a CB jaw-jackin', blacktop fast-trackin', madcap dash across 1970s America for 2-4 players. The goal of the game is for your female trucker to make a name for herself by being the first to gain 12 Fame Points and show the boys you can outhaul, outdrive, and outwit every other gearjammer on the road. Put the hammer down as you pick up Commodities and deliver them to cities that demand them for Fame. Earn Action cards for your accomplishments and use them to dominate the highway as you become a truck driving legend! Just be sure to steer clear of old smokey...

On each turn, a player rolls the Movement Die and optionally the Speeding Die if they wish to attempt speeding. Speeding can allow for an extra Movement point per turn, but can cause wasted fuel trying to avoid the cops if they catch you.

The player may then split their Movement between physically moving road spaces on the map, refueling, and picking up or dropping off loads in cities. Each road space costs 10% fuel and players are towed to the connected city of another player's choice if they run out of fuel.

Contracts offer incentives to deliver certain types of goods or travel to specific regions for bonus Fame. Action cards spice up the game by creating risky scenarios for extra Fame such as Bar Brawls and Street Chicken. Or, play devious deeds against your opponents such as shooting out their gas tanks and stealing their loads. Naturally, all cards are flavored with classic 1970s CB jargon.

The players are collectors of old money, and their aim is to collect more and more coins, old bank notes, bills, and assemble a valuable collection of them. They can also sell these collections throughout the game, to make an extra profit by the end of the game. The player who knows the most about the acquired art treasure's historical background, can make lavish benefits quickly, but who has less knowledge can also get one copy released for auction, with the help of an expert. Knowledge or tactics may prove better? Whoever collects the most forints by the end of the game, will be the most succesful numismatic and the winner of the game. The game was created with educational purpose, and its aim is to present and teach Hungarian history. Every thesis has five questions, specific fot that era, which must be answered correctly to win the subject of auction. If someone doesn't know the correct answer for the question, he/she can hire the other players as experts, who will get payment for the right answer from the principal. The biggest income can be reached by selling collections during the game.

Palette Swap is a 2-4 player logic puzzle game in which you are given a 'palette' of primary colors that you mix, match, and swap with your fellow artists in order to complete your schemes to win the game. If you're clever you can complete multiple schemes in a single turn, and close attention is rewarded if another artist creates the scheme you were after when it's not your turn.

On your turn, you may spend two of the five colors in your palette for their effects. Red allows you to match the colors your opponents have, yellow lets you mix your colors and theirs together, and blue lets you swap a color from your palette with one of another player's colors. Playing two primary colors gets you a secondary color, which simply combines the effects of the two primaries. Playing two secondary colors get you a black, which you must use on your next turn and costs you your secondary colors.

As you change the colors you possess and your opponent's, you will be able to complete your goals, all of which are based on actual color schemes such as split complimentary and analogous schemes. Accomplishing all five of your schemes first makes you the victor.

The game also includes cooperative rules for playing with younger children and rules for solo play.

Pick a power on your card and compare it with the values on the other players´cards. The players win or lose cards on each round, and the last player with cards left wins the game.
This Deck is specifically dedicated to Donatello even if all the Ninja Turtles Characters are present

name.value: Pocket Neon City RUMBLE: Clash of the Gems

item.description:
From the publisher:

Pocket N30N City RUMBLE (PK NCR) is a light dueling card game that simulates a fight between teams of mutant street fighters. Players use three fighters to perform a wide array of attacks, combos,counters,and super moves to beat the living gems out of their opponents. The match is over when a player has lost all of the gems on his or her fighters. A session consists of three matches, with the winner being the player who won two out of three matches.

This game simulates a soccer game. The player who manages to get the ball into the goal of his oppenent wins the game. Movement of the pawns is determined by a die. The moving pawns kick the ball forward and end their movement one space behind the ball. One space can hold more than one pawn and the ball.

name.value: Bienvenido de Nuevo a la Mazmorra
Καλώς Ήλθατε και Πάλι στο Dungeon
Καλώς Ήρθατε και Πάλι στο Dungeon

item.description:
The sun is shining in the Abysmal Woods where you’re strolling without a care in the world, your weapon at your belt, dreams of adventure in your head. On your path, you stop before a damaged dungeon door. It seems that great battles took place here, a sure sign of coveted treasure inside.

You recognize this dungeon from the ballads sung in your village! However, you’re not the only one who wants to enter, despite the warnings left around the entrance by the previous adventurers. Will you muster your courage to break open the door or will you let your opponents brave the monsters found inside? Let the adventure begin!

Welcome Back to the Dungeon is a simple and subtle push-your-luck game in which you’ll need to adopt a show of bravado or outwit your opponents!

link.value: Welcome Back to the Dungeon: Easter Egg
Welcome to the Dungeon: Toad Promo

item.description:
Strategy and conquest in Ming Dynasty China

36 stratagems is a game for 2-3 players, which is set in the Ming Dynasty era in China and neighbouring states. You are the leader of one of several rival families aspiring to become emperor of the entire region. You start the game in a capital city, with just an aspiring emperor, a scout and a small army. The aim of the game is to become the dominant dynasty by conquering and maintaining control of capitals, temples and prefectures. Each of these actions will help you in gaining the victory points needed to be the undisputed emperor and win the game. To be successful you will need to manage your budding empire carefully. Manage your economy through taxation and expanding your population, secure stability by maintaining cohesion among the political elite, maintain a strong military through recruitment of units supported by powerful generals and avoid rebellion by gaining popularity with your subjects. You face an uncertain destiny and will encounter many challenges during your reign including plague, piracy and looting. However, you are not alone in your quest, as to help you gain the power you so richly deserve and to undermine your pitiful and unworthy enemies, you can call upon the ancient Chinese wisdom enshrined in the 36 stratagems.

item.description:
New Year, New Challenge!

Each year the greatest gnome tinkerer, Mastermind, takes on a new apprentice. Becoming this apprentice is a most coveted position, bringing with it the chance to learn skills and techniques that most only dream of; not to mention the prestigious work afterward. You will play as an up-and-coming gnomish tinkerer fighting for your place as Mastermind’s protégé at this year’s competition. Mastermind chooses this apprentice each year by their ability to finish a single task. It will be your job to destroy a Masterbot; a steamwork contraption Mastermind has designed and built to attack your workshop.

				
					Play

Each player receives a game board, a player placard for tracking resources, a gnome character, and a starter bot they can build to help defend their workshop from Masterminds Masterbot. 
Players take turns playing their characters and Mastermind. On Mastermind’s turn all the players decide the actions of the Masterbot attacking the player to their left , while the players attempt to defend their workshop from destruction. On the players turn dice are rolled to gather resources. Bots are then bought, scrapped, or built. If a bot has been built, the player then has the option to attack and try to take out Mastermind’s machine.

				
					Objective

Players must succeed in destroying their assigned Masterbot before the competition can destroy theirs. Sounds easy enough, but the other competitors will try to sabotage you at every turn even while trying to destroy their Masterbots.

The labyrinth in the magic garden is constantly changing. By clever rotating the magical hedges, players open new paths to mysterious creatures and precious treasures. Magic cards help to fulfill the tasks. Who masters the turns and finds his way out of the magic garden first?

A new twist at the changing labyrinth. This time, the paths are bordered by hedges, which can be rotated to change the paths.

Each player has a stack of cards that direct him to various places in the labyrinth. In his turn, the player moves his pawn along the path; he may also rotate one hedge before, during or after his move. If he reaches his current target, he turns his next target card face up. Otherwise, he gets a magic card as consolation.

The magic cards can be used during a players turn to aid movement. A hole allows to slip through a hedge. Two fairies allow to fly from one fairy spot to another one, ignoring the terrain in between. A player may use any number of magic cards in his turn.

After a player has visited the targets on his six cards, the other players decide which exit he needs to reach to win the game.

link.value: Das verdrehte Labyrinth: Happy Meal Edition

item.description:
Barely Balanced is a quick game of daredevil antics and reckless stupidity in which you try to create an acrobatic show that would strike fear into the hearts of insurance adjusters everywhere.

Game play - Each round players start with a hand of 6 cards. The goal is to play tricks using the cards in their hand. Players my trade cards from the table or draw more cards from the deck. The player to play all their cards take the round, but all the tricks played by everyone are scored. Once a single player has taken 3 round the game ends. The player who has scored the most points over the course of the total rounds wins the game.

Game play was influenced by French Tarot and Japaneses Hanafuda and other classic card games.

The Barely Balanced card game is based on the Comedic/Acrobatic stunt show Barely Balanced.

Barely Balanced game was designed as promotional product for the group by designer Max Holliday. Max had been a fan of the acrobatic group for a few years, and while watching a show at the Bristal Ren Fair came up with the game. He proposed the game as soon as the show ended.

From the back of the box:

Take your knowledge to the mat with this fascinating trivia game about wrestling! Young people can play with the old "pros"... Everybody wins! - But there is only one champion!

800 World Wrestling Federation Trivia Questions. Go for that World Wrestling Federation Championship belt... Flaunt your knowledge... Display your acting talents... Pin you Opponents! Create your own "Dream Team".

At the end of the tournament - Claim the "Prize" (The best spot in front of the TV?) - Until the next match.

Description from the publisher:

Amallian was an amazing kingdom, with lush forests, amazing coasts, cuddly martial artists, and the best Emperor known. The one downside of living there was the constant infighting of the clans. They not only disagreed about the way the empire was built, but the way they traded with their neighbors, too.

The clans didn't agree on much, but the Emperor decreed that there was to be no open fighting amongst them. This "peace" lasted for many years. Then came the storm of all storms. Sweeping many clans away, the Emperor was lost for solutions — but then in the Osae Valley, a mist had appeared, and those who entered it were transported to a new land. The Emperor decreed that all clans should venture forth and settle their new empire.

As they did, the oversight was little to none...which lead to the clans competing for the favor of the Emperor by any means necessary. Now the clans of Amallian race to win the favor of the Emperor by building her Empire, trading goods, and showing the most strength on the other side!

In Legends of the Mist, you take on the role of a legend from one of the four clans. By rolling dice from your pool, you can work to build the Emperor's new kingdom with new plots, fight to control them, produce goods from them, and gain wealth for your clan and the kingdom. Each die type has a different frequency of letting you perform these actions. The other clans will work to undermine you every now and again and since dice are assigned in secret, your planning and foresight are important.

Should you complete the objectives that the Empress gave you better than anyone else, you will be rewarded as the winner of her favor!

item.description:
Merchants of Medieval Europe
Game by Alex Fiks; Art Design by Daniel Chou; Published by CHOU! Games; Ages 12+; Players 3-6; Game Time 45-120 min.

Contents: 180 good crate cards, 6 Pawns, 6 quarter mats, 54 poker cards, 18 slider clips, 8 colored discs, 1 Manual.

Introduction
Become a merchant traveling across a section of Western Europe. Leave your family and home with 5 coin in your pocket and try to make a living buying and selling goods for the best price at the whims of the fluctuating market. During your travels one thing becomes clear: the road to success is laden with risk!

Buy silk, wine, spice and more all from historically accurate locations. Borrow funds from the Merchant Bank of Europe and accept contracts from wealthy nobles to find and deliver prized goods. Stake your family's livelihood on one big deal or diversify your goods!
 Will you build a merchant house that will last for eternity, admired by princes and princesses while your merchant rivals suffer in silence surrounded by pestilence and disease for generations to come?

Gameplay
A Round
Every round has two phases. Phases are linear. A round ends when every player has taken a turn. 
Market Phase
1. The first player flips a market card and places it on top of the market discard deck.
2. Players adjust the market good trackers to their new values dictated by the drawn market card.
Action Phase
1. The first player begins their turn and takes up to four actions.
2. Play continues clockwise until every player completes their turn.

A Turn
A player can take up to four actions per turn in any order and can repeat an action any number of times until they run out of actions.
A. Move their token: A player can move their token from a region to an adjacent region. Their token can be upgraded to move 
 farther for a one-time fee.
B. Accept a Contract: A player can accept a contract by drawing two cards and choosing one from the top of the contract deck. Its details can be kept secret or made public. Contracts can’t be discarded until completed.
C. Buy: A player can buy as many goods as they can afford from the resources stockpile, so long as they are in a region that sells the desired good and the good is in stock. Purchased goods are placed on the player’s cart/wagon mat.
D. Sell / Fulfill a Contract: From any region, a player can sell any number of goods back to the stockpile for their current market value as dictated by the Perimeter Market. Alternatively, they can fulfill a contract by selling a designated number of goods to a designated region, according to the contract card, at their current value plus a bonus as indicated by the contract.

Additionally, the following decisions do not expend an action and can be done during a player's turn at any time:
1. Upgrading from a cart to a wagon.
2. Incurring or paying back bank debt.

Version of Monopoly - Kraków Edition.

The game uses all of the rules and values (prices, tax), money and pawns from the standard Monopoly game.

Changes:
- Names of places to buy (properties, utilities) were changes to the know places in Kraków
- Board is lustrated with photos from the city
- Community chest & chance cards have city related flavor texts

Extra:
- The game contains one Top Trumps card - Wawel Royal Castle

H.E.A.D. Hunters is a card-driven miniatures game for two or more players. Each player controls their own 5.25" Hero of Every Age & Dimension (H.E.A.D.) Hunter Toy that stores all the components of the game in its head. Inside each H.E.A.D. Hunter is its own themed deck of cards, battle bases, measuring string and combat dice.

The starter pack includes Erik Thanessen (Viking) & Xeno X9 (Robot). Cards from other H.E.A.D. Hunters can be mixed and matched to customize the player's deck, matching their own play style.

Each character has a unique set of starting terrain as part of their deck that can be placed in a multitude of positions and layouts to create unlimited fields of battle. Once these are placed, the players draw and play cards to attack and defend against other Hunters as they move their toy around the table for position and opportunity; where you attack from is as important as what you attack with!

Game play continues until one Hunter is left standing, but be warned: As players take and inflict damage, unique character abilities are enabled which can turn the tide of the game. When the game is over, all the components fit back inside the head while the toy sits patiently (and attractively) on your shelf, waiting for its next opponent.

item.description:
From the box:

The original Five Suit Game.

Official American Rules for Five Suit Castle Bridge.

Originated 1933 by Ammiel F. Decker

Each player has a set of four pawns that start in his or her side of the board. The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the "Ziel" section. Movement is determined by a die. All players move clockwise around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Whenever a pawn arrives on a space as the result of a die-roll, it advances by the number of spaces shown on that space. If a pawn arrives on a red space, it advances into an inner ring. The pawns have to circle the innermost ring, till they manage to enter their "Ziel" section. Captured pawns are returned to their player's "Start" section. The winner is the first player to move all pawns into the "Ziel" section.
This game was published about 1930.

name.value: Elections of US America Election: The Card Game

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Elections of US America Election: The Card Game brings together the best snark of political website Wonkette with the game design smarts of game developer Auroch Digital’s ‘GameTheNews’ initiative to create the greatest social card game in political history, mostly because it’s the FIRST ONE IN HISTORY TOO! (Maybe.)

You as the player take on the role of a campaign manager backing a candidate(past, present or fictional). Each turn you have a choice, go for votes or play a Wonk card. Wonk cards will either up your candidate's Independant, Republican and/or Democrat appeal, or damage your opponents.

The player with the most voter points at the end of the round wins the state. Each state card has electoral college votes, to win a short game you need to be the first player to reach 70 electoral college votes with at least 4 state cards, or go for the long haul you need to be the first to 270 electoral college votes. 
So, will you play fair and hope winning over the voters will get your candidate into the White House or sling mud like the best of them and go down fighting?

From the publisher:

WizArt is a strategy card game for 2-3 players where you try to acquire knowledge from 3 different magic schools (the cosmic, the elemental or the temporal) in order to graduate as a mage faster than your opponents. To win the game, you must play cards and invest knowledge crystals. If you played well, you will then be able to level up at the beginning of your turn and acquire more power. Depending on the cards that you play, you will be able to use crystals of your opponents. If you reach mage level 5 or if you have eliminated all other players, you win.

WizArt is an exciting strategy card game with a lot of player interaction which is easy to learn but hard to master. It takes about 30 minutes to play and is suitable for players who are 8 years or older.

The players have to move their pawn from the starting point to one of the yellow or red spaces in the center of the game board. The red and yellow dice determine movement on the game track, while the green symbol die controls movement on the checkered center section by one or two spaces each turn. The results of the yellow and red dice are translated by each player's dice result card. Possible outcomes are forward movement (V), backward movement (Z) or no movement at all (Symbol).

The Corner spaces have the following meanings:
V - move forward to the next red triangle
Z - move backward to the last yellow triangle
Symbol - miss your next turn
black spot - return to the black starting space

The game was likely published in the 1920s.

From the publisher:

Ready, set, sumo! Japan's centuries-old national sport is the main attraction in this paper-based smackdown where creativity and competition collide. The result? Laughs guaranteed! There is an impressive assortment of 39 characters—from traditional sumo wrestlers to animals to monsters and other eye-catching creatures from Japanese lore. Additional characters can be created by drawing on customizable shapes. Then battle it out against an opponent's character on the sumo doyho ring. With each player tapping on his or her side of the doyho, the stakes are high until one of the characters falls and the other wins!

Each player has to move his 16 meeples from his starting positions around the game board and over his launching pad (the five spaces of his own color) to the blue "luck" space at the center of the game board. Movement is done one space along the black lines or by jumping over other meeples, regardles if they're own or opponent ones. Each meeple reaching it's own launching pad, immediately goes to the "luck" space and is taken out of the game. The first player to get all his meeples on the "luck" space wins the game.

Catacombs is an award-winning, cooperative board game set in the fantasy world of Cimathue, and you need skill and dexterity to master this fast-paced game.

One player (the Overseer) marshals an army of monsters while the others choose from six brave heroes who embark on a quest to save the town of Stormtryne from the threat lurking in the catacombs below. As the heroes explore, they must use their abilities, buy items, and recruit allies to help them defeat the monsters before facing the powerful Catacomb Lord, thereby saving the town.

In more detail, in Catacombs players flick wooden discs that represent the monsters and heroes. Contact with an opposing piece inflicts damage, while missiles, spells, and other special abilities can cause other effects. When all of the monsters of a room have been cleared, the heroes can move further into the catacomb.

Items and equipment upgrades can be purchased from the Merchant with gold taken from fallen monsters. The Catacomb Lord is the final danger that the heroes must defeat to win the game. Conversely, the Overseer wins if all of the heroes are defeated.

This third edition of Catacombs has all-new artwork compared to the earlier editions, but more importantly the keywords from the first two editions has been replace with iconography, the terminology has changed, and the third edition has new shot types, new card effects, and a different set of components (many of which have changed statistics) as well as wall pieces not present in earlier editions.

link.value: Catacombs: Dice Tower 2018 Kickstarter Promo Pack

item.description:
A monstrous board game encouraging kids & families to have imaginative fun with game play imaginative interaction!

A classic dungeon setting is the backdrop as players assume the roles of tough hunters bound and determined to do three things: to defeat as many monsters as possible, to collect treasure, and to make it out unscathed.

Players become bona fide monster hunters as they delve into dungeons filled with beasts and obstacles. At the beginning of each session, players choose one of three game modes in which they will compete. Treasure Hunt, Monster Hunt, or Dungeon Escape.

At the beginning of each session, players choose one of three game modes in which they will compete:

Treasure Hunt – Be the first to get to the treasure

Monster Hunt – Defeat all the monsters on the board, player with the most captured wins

Dungeon Escape – Be the first player to get to the finish exit

Up to 4 boards can be arranged in numerous ways based on the number of players. Obstacle tiles including corridors, pits, locked doors, and secret doors are added to the boards. The number depends on the game mode being played. Monsters are then added to the board.

Each player rolls a d10 for movement through squares that make up the dungeon boards. When they get to obstacles they must make an extra roll to get past them. Sometimes loosing a turn, or having to turn around and find another path. When players encounter monsters they must reference the Monster's card to see how to defeat them. Examples are an opposing roll of the the die, rolling an odd number, rolling 7 or higher.

name.value: DETHRONED: The Real-Time Combat Card Game

item.description:
DETHRONED is what happens when a game developer is forced to play too much Mafia. DETHRONED takes the hidden-role genre and makes it faster, giving the power to kill in YOUR HANDS.

Simple enough for parties, meta enough for board game geeks.

A dynamic card game fusing Real-Time combat with the hidden-role genre.

No turns. No waiting. Just lies and murder!

DETHRONED, the whole game is a set that comes with 2 decks:
-Traitors and Kings & Guards and Thieves-

Each with their own theme, unique art, and lore. They can be played completely independently up to 4, OR together for up to 8 player chaos and fun!

Players first begin by going around the table claiming a role. Depending on the role you secretly got will help determine if you should lie about your role, though you never have to. After that, players continue discussing until 2 players vote to begin combat.

Once combat begins, players may attack each other at any point in time, until someone dies. Every time someone dies, combat is paused and a vote to end the game goes up. All living players must unanimously vote to end and to not vote yes, you have to attack another player, if you cannot then you're forced to vote yes to end. The game can only end in a stalemate (players reveal hands to prove such) OR after a player has died.

Once the game ends, roles are revealed and winners are determined based on the role's win conditions.

name.value: Project Z: The Zombie Miniatures Game

item.description:
Fight the Dead, Fight the Living

Fight to survive in the abandoned streets of a post-apocalyptic world infested by unnatural creatures hungry for your flesh.

Scavenge for scarce supplies whilst battling against the dead and the living alike; there are no laws, there are no rules, only the fight.

Project Z is a skirmish wargame for 1 to 3 players taking control of Survivors or a Street Gang fighting to survive against the environment and an ever-growing horde of Zombies. Project Z is a fast and easy to learn game containing 39 detailed self-assembly plastic models, rules, counters and specially designed dice and cards.

item.description:
Plague Inc: The Board Game is a strategic game of infection, evolution and extinction for 1-5* people - based on the smash-hit digital game with over 85 million players. Can you infect the world?

Each player is a deadly disease and they must battle against each other to spread their plagues, develop new symptoms and ultimately wipe out humanity.

Starting with Patient Zero, you spread your infection across the world by placing tokens in cities - earning DNA points and preventing other players from becoming dominant. Players choose which countries are placed on the board but you must be both climate resistant and connected to a country before you can infect it. Eventually, as countries become fully infected - you try to kill them using the Death Dice.

Each player’s unique pathogen can be upgraded by evolving trait cards onto an evolution slide (with DNA points). At the start, your disease is weak and unspecialised, so you will need to add new symptoms to make it stronger. Choose carefully and plan ahead in order to react to the changing world and exploit opportunities created by other player’s actions.

A simple nosebleed could accelerate things early on, whilst diarrhea will help you thrive in hot countries. Sneezing can infect new continents by air but Total Organ Failure would allow you wipe out multiple countries each turn.

As countries start to fall, use powerful event cards to alter the balance of power. You might try to eradicate a dominant player by bombing their diseased cities, or hold the Olympics to cause huge numbers of infected people to travel to a healthy continent.

When the world collapses, who will be the ultimate plague?


*5 players with 5th player expansion

Saami is a semi-cooperative game in which players need to eliminate threats while trying to improve their own personal position in the game.

item.description: The players have to move their four cubes from the diagonaly opposite corner to the nest of their color. Movement to a neighboring space is achieved by tilting the cube by 90 degree, thereby changing the Image on the top of the cube. The movement can be continued in a straight line as Long as thre are unoccupied spaces. If two cubes are sitting next to or pass each other, the stronger image kills the weeker one (hunter - Fox - weasel - chicken - frog - gnat). The strongest Image is the hunter but he can be killed by the weakest, which is the gnat. Killed cubes are removed from the game. Cubes that have entered their own nest must show the correct animal on top to be saved. A saved animal counts 3 points and the cubes on the board of the last player count 2 points at the end of the game.
